rangees.data: Posterior border of calcaneus (via Achilles tendon)

content.subtitle: Subject positioning
text: Prone position, ankle and foot in dorsiflexion, extending beyond the end of the table

content.subtitle: Anatomical landmarks and palpation
text: Locate and palpate the Achilles tendon to its calcaneal insertion at the posterior midline of the lower calf[5]

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: Examination of the peritendinous sheath of the Achilles tendon[4]
positionnement: Place the probe in longitudinal view (along the long axis of the tendon), approximately five centimeters above (cranial) the medial malleolus
Slowly oscillate the probe medio-laterally across the calf to cover its entire surface
Then evaluate the junction by scanning in a cranio-caudal axis to properly observe the transition between the soleus and Achilles tendon

texte: The soleus muscle appears as a hypoechoic area with a striated pattern characteristic of muscle tissue
The Achilles tendon appears as a hyperechoic band with a clearly visible fibrillar pattern

text: The soleus muscle is a powerful plantar flexor of the ankle. Unlike the gastrocnemius, which is biarticular (crossing both knee and ankle joints), the soleus is monoarticular, crossing only the ankle joint. This anatomical characteristic makes it particularly important for postural control and standing balance.

The soleus muscle has a complex architecture, with multiple pennation angles and aponeuroses. Its fibers converge into the Achilles tendon, which it shares with the gastrocnemius muscle. The junction between the soleus muscle and the Achilles tendon is a common site for strain injuries, particularly in athletes.

The musculotendinous junction of the soleus with the Achilles tendon is an area of particular clinical interest, as it is often involved in various pathological conditions. This junction represents a transition zone where muscle tissue gradually gives way to tendinous tissue, creating a region of potential mechanical stress.

content.subtitle: Soleus strain
text: Soleus muscle strains often occur at or near the musculotendinous junction with the Achilles tendon. These injuries are particularly common in athletes involved in running and jumping sports.

The diagnosis of soleus strains can be challenging clinically, as symptoms may mimic those of Achilles tendinopathy or gastrocnemius strains. Ultrasound examination allows for precise localization of the injury and assessment of its severity.

content.subtitle: Achilles tendinopathy
text: The soleus-Achilles tendon junction is a common site for the development of tendinopathy. The transition zone between muscle and tendon tissue can be subject to increased mechanical stress, particularly during repetitive activities.

Ultrasound examination can help differentiate between various types of Achilles tendinopathy and determine the exact location of pathological changes, which is crucial for appropriate treatment planning.
